questions.text: Ultrasound works based on the principle of?
questions.solution:
Explanation

Ultrasound machines operate based on the principle of piezoelectric crystal excitation.

  • An ultrasound (sonographic/echographic) image is formed by the mechanical oscillations of piezoelectric crystals that are excited by electrical pulses. This phenomenon is known as the piezoelectric effect.
  • The tip of an ultrasound transducer is made up of these piezoelectric crystals, such as lead zirconate titanate.
  • When an electric current passes through the transducer, these crystals vibrate, producing ultrasound waves.
  • These waves propagate through different tissues and are then reflected back. The transducer crystals then convert these reflected waves back into electrical impulses.
  • These impulses are further processed to form an ultrasound image on the screen, utilizing the pulse-echo principle.

Explanation of Other Options:

Very low frequency radiowaves (Option B): Very low frequency radiowaves or radiowaves in general are used in MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) scans, not in ultrasound.

Microwaves (Option C): Microwaves are a type of electromagnetic radiation used in various applications (e.g., microwave ovens, radar) but are not the primary principle behind diagnostic ultrasound imaging.

Linear attenuation of X-rays (Option D): The linear attenuation of X-rays describes how X-ray beams lose intensity as they pass through matter, which is the fundamental principle of X-ray imaging and CT scans, not ultrasound.

Key Takeaway:

Ultrasound imaging fundamentally relies on the piezoelectric effect, where special crystals in the transducer convert electrical energy into sound waves and vice versa, using the pulse-echo principle to generate images.

questions.text: What is the frequency of sound waves used for transabdominal ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
Explanation

The frequency of sound waves typically used for transabdominal ultrasonography is 3.5-5.0 MHz.

  • Transabdominal ultrasonography is an imaging technique that utilizes lower-frequency sound waves to effectively penetrate through the abdominal wall. This allows for visualization of deep structures such as the uterus, ovaries, and other abdominal organs.
  • For routine abdominal USG, the frequency range is generally 3.5 - 5 MHz.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • 2.5-3.5 MHz (Option A): While this is a lower frequency, the standard range for transabdominal USG is generally given as 3.5-5.0 MHz for optimal balance of penetration and resolution.
  • 5.0-7.5 MHz (Option C): This higher frequency range is typically used for Transvaginal/Transrectal USG, where closer proximity to the organs allows for better resolution with higher frequencies.
  • 7.5-10 MHz (Option D): This even higher frequency range (often extending to 12 MHz) is used for superficial USG (e.g., orbit, thyroid, breast) where high resolution is needed for structures close to the skin surface, with less need for deep penetration.

Key Takeaway:

Transabdominal ultrasonography utilizes lower frequency sound waves (3.5-5.0 MHz) to achieve sufficient penetration for imaging deep abdominal structures, distinguishing it from higher frequency probes used for superficial or endocavitary imaging.

questions.text: Which of the following is anechoic on ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
Explanation

A simple cyst is anechoic on ultrasonography (USG).

  • Anechoic means that no echoes are produced from within the structure. This occurs when there is no difference in acoustic density within the structure, allowing sound waves to pass through unimpeded.
  • Homogeneous fluids, like those typically found in a simple cyst, transmit sound exceptionally well. Because the sound passes through without reflection, the area appears black on the ultrasound image.
  • Furthermore, these fluids cause increased echoes in structures deeper to them (posterior enhancement) due to minimal attenuation of the sound beam.

Explanation of Other Options:

Air (Option A): Air is hyperechoic (bright) and causes dirty shadowing on ultrasound because it reflects and scatters almost all the sound waves, preventing sound from passing deeper. It is not anechoic.

Skull bones (Option C): Skull bones are hyperechoic (bright) and cause posterior acoustic shadowing because they strongly reflect and absorb the ultrasound waves, preventing sound from passing through.

Calcifications (Option D): Calcifications (e.g., gallstones, kidney stones, calcified vessels) are also hyperechoic(very bright) and cause strong posterior acoustic shadowing due to their dense nature, which blocks the passage of sound waves.

Key Takeaway:

On ultrasonography, anechoic structures appear black and are characteristic of simple fluid-filled entities like cysts, which allow sound waves to pass through without generating internal echoes. Dense structures like bone, calcifications, and air appear bright and cause shadowing.

choices.text: To allow for better propagation of waves
It acts as an acoustic window

questions.text: A young female is brought to the radiology unit with a suspected case of PCOD, she is advised to undergo an ultrasound. The radiologist asked the female if she had taken enough water and if her bladder was full. Why is it advised to have a full bladder before trans-abdominal ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Explanation

A full bladder is advised before a trans-abdominal ultrasound because it acts as an acoustic window.

  • A full bladder serves as a reservoir of fluid that enhances the movement of sound waves through the abdominal cavity.
  • This acoustic window is a "small opening" through which sound waves can pass, helping to image the structures beyond it.
  • Ultimately, this allows for a clearer view of the internal structures that need to be observed, such as the uterus and ovaries, for conditions like PCOD.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • To increase impedance (Option A): Increasing impedance would generally hinder sound wave propagation, leading to more reflection and less penetration, which is contrary to the goal of a full bladder for imaging.
  • To allow for better propagation of waves (Option B): While a full bladder does allow for better propagation of waves, this is a consequence of it acting as an acoustic window, not the fundamental reason or the most precise explanation. The term "acoustic window" best describes its function.
  • It is a malpractice (Option C): Advising a full bladder for trans-abdominal pelvic ultrasound is a standard and correct practice, not a malpractice.

Key Takeaway:

For trans-abdominal pelvic ultrasonography, a full bladder is essential as it creates an acoustic window, facilitating the clear passage of ultrasound waves and improving the visualization of deeper pelvic organs by displacing bowel gas and providing a consistent fluid medium.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presented with an acute onset of pain in the right limb. An investigation was performed. Identify the investigation performed, which is shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation

The provided image displays spectral Doppler waveforms, indicating that the investigation performed is an Ultrasound Doppler.

  • Doppler ultrasound is a non-invasive imaging technique that uses sound waves to evaluate blood flow through blood vessels.
  • The Doppler effect is the principle behind it, resulting from an apparent shift in sound frequency as sound waves are reflected from moving targets, primarily blood cells.
  • In Color Doppler, the type of color represents the direction of flow: red typically indicates flow towards the probe, and blue indicates flow away from the probe. The intensity of the color is based on the velocity of the flow.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Digital subtraction angiography (Option A): This is an invasive procedure that involves injecting iodinated contrast and taking sequential X-ray images, with computer processing to remove background bone and soft tissue, to visualize blood vessels. It produces images of the vessel lumen, not spectral waveforms.
  • Plethysmography (Option C): Plethysmography measures changes in volume in a part of the body, often used to assess blood flow (e.g., arterial or venous insufficiency), but does not produce a visual image of blood flow or vessels like the one shown.
  • MR Angiography (Option D): MR Angiography (MRA) uses Magnetic Resonance Imaging to visualize blood vessels, often with contrast agents. It produces cross-sectional images or 3D reconstructions of vessels, not spectral waveforms as seen in the image.

Key Takeaway:

The presence of spectral Doppler waveforms in the image is the definitive indicator of an Ultrasound Doppler examination, a non-invasive method for assessing blood flow.

questions.text: Characteristics of the venous blood flow of the lower limb in duplex Doppler?
questions.solution:
Explanation

Normal venous blood flow in the lower limb, as seen on Doppler ultrasound, typically exhibits a monophasic pattern with phasicity related to respiration.

  • The normal venous waveform shows variation (phasicity) secondary to respiration, referred to as a respirophasic waveform. This means the flow velocity changes with inspiration and expiration.
  • A loss of this phasic variation, resulting in a monophasic waveform without respiratory variation, is suggestive of venous obstruction proximal to the level of interrogation. However, the characteristic normal flow is described as monophasic with this respiratory variability, distinguishing it from arterial flow patterns.

Explanation of Other Options:

Biphasic (Option B): Venous blood flow will not show a biphasic pattern. Biphasic patterns are characteristic of some arterial flows, typically in intermediate resistance arterial beds.

Triphasic (Option C): A triphasic pattern is characteristic of high-resistance arterial blood flow, typically found in peripheral arteries, not venous blood.

Non-Phasic (Option D): A non-phasic pattern (continuous flow without respiratory variation) in venous blood is suggestive of occlusion or thrombus. While it indicates pathology, the normal flow is monophasic with respiratory phasicity.

Key Takeaway:

Normal venous blood flow in the lower limb is characterized by a monophasic pattern that varies with respiration (respirophasic). Loss of this phasicity indicates proximal venous obstruction.

questions.text: A lactating woman with a painful breast, the 1st investigation to be done is?
questions.solution:
Explanation

For a lactating woman presenting with a painful breast, the first-line investigation to be done is an Ultrasound (USG).

  • USG is preferred in pregnant women, lactating women, and young women (less than 40 years) because breast tissue is dense in these populations, making mammography less effective.
  • USG is the investigation of choice (IOC) for suspected breast abscess (a common cause of painful breast in lactating women).
  • USG is also the IOC for other fluid collections like pericardial effusion (using 2D echo), minimal pleural effusion, ascites/hemoperitoneum, and hydronephrosis/hydrocele, and for differentiating between solid and cystic areas.

Explanation of Other Options:

Mammography (Option B): Mammography is less effective in lactating women due to the dense breast tissue, which can obscure findings and reduce sensitivity. It also involves radiation exposure.

CT scan (Option C): A CT scan involves ionizing radiation and provides cross-sectional images, but it is not the primary investigation for painful breast in lactating women due to radiation exposure and less detailed visualization of breast tissue compared to USG.

MRI scan (Option D): MRI is a highly sensitive imaging modality for breast evaluation but is not typically the first-line investigation for painful breast in a lactating woman due to its high cost, limited availability, and potential need for contrast, unless other modalities are inconclusive or specific complex issues are suspected.

Key Takeaway:

For a lactating woman with a painful breast, Ultrasound (USG) is the initial and preferred imaging modality due to its ability to differentiate fluid collections (like abscesses) in dense breast tissue without radiation.

choices.text: USG in a patient with Pleural effusion
USG in a patient with Hemothorax
USG in a patient with Pneumothorax

questions.text: The Seashore sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
Explanation

The Seashore sign is a normal finding observed during a lung ultrasound (USG) on M-mode.

  • In a normal chest, the Seashore sign visually represents the sliding motion of the visceral and parietal pleura. On an M-mode display, the static chest wall (above the pleura) appears as horizontal lines (like the sky), while the moving lung parenchyma (below the pleura) creates a granular, sandy appearance (like the seashore), with a clear boundary resembling the "seashore" itself where the two meet.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • USG in a patient with Pleural effusion (Option A): While ultrasound is used to detect pleural effusion, pleural effusion itself does not manifest as a "seashore sign." Pleural effusion would appear as an anechoic (black) collection of fluid in the pleural space, often with lung collapse.
  • USG in a patient with Hemothorax (Option B): Hemothorax (blood in the pleural space) would appear as a collection of fluid (often complex, with echoes or septations) in the pleural space, similar to effusion but with internal echogenicity, not as a "seashore sign."
  • USG in a patient with Pneumothorax (Option C): In a patient with pneumothorax, the Seashore sign is absent. Instead, on M-mode ultrasound, pneumothorax typically presents with a "Stratosphere sign" or "Barcode sign", where both the chest wall and the underlying lung appear as horizontal lines due to the absence of pleural sliding caused by air between the pleura.

Key Takeaway:

The Seashore sign on M-mode lung ultrasound is a normal finding indicating healthy pleural sliding. Its absence and the presence of a "Stratosphere" or "Barcode" sign are highly indicative of a pneumothorax.

choices.text: Focused assessment by sonography for trauma
Focused assessment by sonography and tomography
Fast assessment by sonography and trauma

questions.text: What is the Full form of FAST?
questions.solution:
Explanation

The full form of FAST is Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma.

  • FAST is a non-invasive, rapid bedside ultrasound examination.
  • It is used to evaluate all trauma patients for free fluid in potential body cavities, which can indicate internal bleeding.
  • Key views included in a FAST exam are:
    • Pericardial view (Subxiphoid view): To check for fluid around the heart (pericardial effusion), which may indicate cardiac tamponade.
    • Hepatorenal view: To check for free fluid in the hepatorenal recess (Morison's pouch), which may indicate intraperitoneal bleeding.
    • Splenorenal view: To check for free fluid in the splenorenal recess, which may indicate splenic injury or bleeding.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Focused abdominal sonography for trauma (Option A): While it involves abdominal sonography, the accurate and complete acronym includes "assessment by".
  • Focused assessment by sonography and tomography (Option C): This is incorrect as "tomography" (like CT) is a different imaging modality and not part of the "FAST" acronym.
  • Fast assessment by sonography and trauma (Option D): This is incorrect as the first word is "Focused," not "Fast".

Key Takeaway:

FAST stands for Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma, a critical rapid ultrasound exam used in trauma settings to quickly detect free fluid in key body cavities.

Views:

  • Pericardial view(Subxiphoid view): The presence of fluid around the heart (pericardial effusion) may indicate cardiac tamponade.
  • Hepatorenal view: Free fluid in the hepatorenal recess (Morison's pouch) may indicate intraperitoneal bleeding.
  • Splenorenal view: Free fluid in the splenorenal recess may indicate splenic injury or rupture.
  • Pelvic view: Free fluid in the pelvis may indicate intraperitoneal bleeding, often from pelvic fractures or abdominal organ injury.

questions.text: Nuchal Translucency scan is done at?
questions.solution:
Explanation

The Nuchal Translucency (NT) scan is typically performed between 11 and 14 weeks of pregnancy.

  • This ultrasound screening test is used to assess the risk of Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) and other chromosomal abnormalities in the fetus.
  • During the scan, the thickness of the nuchal translucency (the fluid-filled space at the back of the fetus's neck) is measured.
  • Abnormal thickness may indicate an increased risk of certain genetic conditions.
  • Additionally, an absent nasal bone along with increased NT further increases the chances of aneuploidy.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • 8-10 weeks (Option A): This is not the ideal time for performing an NT scan; the fetus is too small, and the nuchal fluid may not be adequately developed for accurate measurement.
  • >14 weeks (Choices C and D): Beyond 14 weeks, the nuchal translucency typically resolves or disperses, making accurate measurement difficult or impossible, and therefore, it is not the ideal time for performing an NT scan.

Key Takeaway:

The Nuchal Translucency (NT) scan is a critical prenatal screening test that must be performed within a narrow gestational window, specifically between 11 and 14 weeks of pregnancy, for accurate assessment of chromosomal abnormalities.

questions.text: A banana sign on Ultrasound is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation

The Banana sign on ultrasound is specifically associated with spina bifida.

  • The Banana sign refers to an abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum along with the effacement (obliteration) of the cisterna magna, which together create this characteristic appearance.
  • This sign is a key indicator in the diagnosis of spina bifida and is also associated with Arnold-Chiari malformation, a common concomitant condition where brain tissue extends into the spinal canal.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anencephaly (Option B): Anencephaly is a severe neural tube defect characterized by the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp. It typically shows a "frog eye sign" on ultrasound, not the banana sign.

Down syndrome (Option C): Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) is a chromosomal abnormality with various ultrasound markers (e.g., increased nuchal translucency, absent nasal bone, duodenal atresia), but the banana sign is not a characteristic feature.

Klinefelter syndrome (Option D): Klinefelter syndrome (XXY) is a sex chromosome aneuploidy that does not typically have specific, identifiable ultrasound signs like the banana sign.

Key Takeaway:

The Banana sign on ultrasound is a crucial indicator for spina bifida, reflecting the associated cerebellar abnormalities and effacement of the cisterna magna, often linked with Arnold-Chiari malformation.

questions.text: The earliest congenital malformation that can be detected on USG?
questions.solution:
Explanation

Anencephaly is the earliest congenital malformation that can be detected on USG (ultrasonography).

  • It is caused by the failure of closure of the anterior neuropore during embryonic development.
  • Anencephaly can be detected on ultrasound as early as 10 weeks of gestation, and the diagnosis can typically be confirmed by 14 weeks.
  • Characteristic signs on USG include the "Mickey Mouse sign" and "frog eye sign".

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Hydrocephalus (Option B): While detectable on USG, hydrocephalus (excess cerebrospinal fluid in the brain) usually becomes apparent later in gestation when ventricular dilation is significant, typically not as early as anencephaly.
  • Sacral agenesis (Option C): Sacral agenesis (absence of sacrum) can be detected on USG, but it is generally not identifiable as early as anencephaly.
  • Down syndrome (Option D): Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) is a chromosomal abnormality, not a single structural malformation like anencephaly. While it has several ultrasound markers (e.g., increased nuchal translucency, absent nasal bone), these are typically screened for at 11-14 weeks (NT scan), and definite structural anomalies often manifest later or are subtle. Diagnosis is confirmed by genetic testing.

Key Takeaway:

Anencephaly, a severe neural tube defect resulting from failure of anterior neuropore closure, is the earliest congenital malformation detectable by ultrasound, often as early as 10 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: Most Accurate fetal biometry parameter for gestational age?
questions.solution:
Explanation

The Crown Rump Length (CRL) is the most accurate fetal biometry parameter for determining gestational age (GA), particularly in the first trimester.

  • CRL is also considered the most accurate parameter for establishing the estimated date of delivery (EDD). Its accuracy decreases after the first trimester due to increasing fetal flexion and extension.
    • Biparietal diameter (BPD) - GA in the second and third trimesters
    • Head circumference - GA in abnormal shape of skull
    • Femur length - GA in late third trimester
    • Abdominal circumference - For fetal growth, IUGR / macrosomia
    • Transcerebellar Diameter - Least affected by IUGR/ GA in IUGR

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Abdominal circumference (AC) (Option B): Abdominal circumference is primarily used for fetal growth assessment (e.g., in cases of Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR) or macrosomia), and not for the initial assessment of gestational age.
  • Biparietal diameter (BPD) (Option C): Biparietal diameter is used to assess GA primarily in the second and third trimesters, but it is not as accurate as CRL for early gestational age determination. Head circumference (HC) is also used for GA, especially when the skull shape is abnormal.
  • Femur length (FL) (Option D): Femur length is used to assess GA in the late third trimester, but it is not as accurate as CRL for initial dating. Transcerebellar Diameter (TCD) is another parameter, noted for being least affected by IUGR and useful for GA in such cases.

Key Takeaway:

For the most accurate determination of gestational age, especially in the first trimester, Crown Rump Length (CRL)is the preferred and most reliable biometric parameter.

choices.text: Death of the foetus in the uterus

questions.text: What does the Spalding sign indicate?
questions.solution:
Explanation

The Spalding sign occurs after the death of the fetus in the uterus.

  • Spalding's sign specifically refers to the overlapping of cranial bones due to fetal molding. This sign typically becomes apparent after 7 days of fetal death in utero.
  • Another sign of fetal demise is Robert's sign, which is the presence of gas in the heart and great vessels, and can be seen as early as 12 hours after fetal death.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Birth of live foetus (Option A): Spalding's sign is an indicator of fetal demise, not the birth of a live fetus.
  • Rigor mortis of infant (Option C): Rigor mortis is a post-mortem stiffening of muscles that occurs after death, but the Spalding sign is a specific radiographic finding related to fetal death in utero and cranial changes.
  • Cadaveric spasm (Option D): Cadaveric spasm is a rare form of instantaneous rigor mortis that occurs at the moment of death, usually associated with violent or stressful deaths. It is not related to the Spalding sign or fetal demise.

Key Takeaway:

The Spalding sign, characterized by the overlapping of fetal cranial bones, is a radiographic indicator of fetal death in utero, typically seen more than 7 days after demise.

choices.text: CBD stones at the distal end of the CBD

questions.text: Which condition is challenging to visualize using an ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Explanation

CBD (Common Bile Duct) stones at the distal end of the CBD are challenging to visualize using ultrasonography.

  • Ultrasonography may not effectively visualize these stones due to poor imaging quality caused by overlying bowel gas or a limited acoustic window in that specific anatomical region. The distal CBD passes through the head of the pancreas and is often obscured by gas in the duodenum.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Breast cyst (Option B): Ultrasonography is highly useful and effective in visualizing breast cysts, often being the modality of choice to differentiate cystic from solid lesions. Cysts typically appear anechoic with posterior enhancement.
  • Ascites (Option C): Ultrasonography is commonly and effectively used to detect ascites (free fluid in the peritoneal cavity), even in small amounts, as fluid is easily visualized as anechoic collections.
  • Full bladder (Option D): A full bladder itself is easily visualized on ultrasonography as an anechoic, fluid-filled structure. A full bladder is often required for optimal visualization of pelvic organs during transabdominal ultrasound because it acts as an acoustic window, displacing bowel gas.

Key Takeaway:

While ultrasound is highly versatile, its effectiveness can be limited by factors like overlying gas. Therefore, CBD stones at the distal end of the CBD represent a particular challenge for ultrasonographic visualization due to anatomical constraints and bowel gas interference.
